Complementary genes

  • Section 1
  • Exercise

It is a hereditary conditions controlled by two pairs of genes. In order for a dominant trait to appear, there must be at least one dominant gene in each pair of genes, so these genes are said to complement each otherâ€™s action. When the two genes in one or both pairs are in a recessive state, the recessive trait appears. An example of this is the inheritance of the colour trait of flowers in pea plants.The appearance of the colour trait of flowers in pea plants is due to the presence of two different pairs of genes; two genes are dominant and are denoted by the two capital letters C and P, while the other two genes are recessive and denoted by the small letters c and p.

On crossing of a white-flowered plant (CCpp) with another white-flowered plant of different genotype (ccPP), first generation (F1) plants all have purple flowers (of genotype CcPp), where a dominant gene from each of these pairs of genes combines with the other and complements its action, thus the dominant trait (purple flowers) appears. When first generation plants (F1) self-pollinate and their seeds are cultivated, second generation plants (F2) grow and produce purple and white flowers at a ratio of 9 purple : 7 white (Figure 1).

Figure (1)
Inheritance of flower colour trait in the pea plant.


The appearance of the dominant trait requires the presence of one or more dominant genes from the two pairs of genes together because the two dominant genes complement each other to show the dominant trait (the purple flower colour). The two genes affect the production of a specific enzyme that stimulates the formation of a specific pigment in flower cells known as anthocyanin.
The validity of this explanation has been proven experimentally, as on mixing an extract produced from two white-flowered plants in a test tube, the purple colour appeared due to the availability of enzymes required for the completion of the reaction. This ratio (9 purple : 7 white) of flower colour in the second generation of pea plants is modified from the Mendelian ratio 9:3:3:1 as three genotypes (3:3:1) all have the same phenotype, that is white flower colour, so the ratio is 9:7.
